section_title: Variables and Data Types in Python
section_description: Learn how to store and manipulate data using Python's built-in types. By the end of this section, you will confidently create variables and convert between common data types.
learning_objectives: Declare variables with descriptive names and assign values of different types
Distinguish between int, float, str, and bool data types and their use cases
Convert variables from one type to another using built-in functions
Predict and trace the output of code that manipulates variables

lessons.lesson_objective: Correctly declare at least three variables with meaningful names and assigned values.

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create variables named first_name, age, and hobby. Assign your own first name, age, and favorite hobby to them. Print each variable on a separate line.
Given the invalid names 2nd_name, last name, and $score, rename them to follow Python conventions and assign any appropriate values.

lessons.lesson_objective: Perform arithmetic operations and correctly choose between int and float types.

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create variables price, quantity, and tax_rate. Calculate and print the total cost including tax, ensuring the result is a float rounded to two decimals.

lessons.lesson_objective: Manipulate strings using at least four different string methods.

exercises.exercise_instructions: Start with the messy string '  HELLO world  '. Remove leading/trailing spaces, convert to title case, and replace 'world' with your name. Print the final result.
Use an f-string to create a sentence that includes variables for adjective, noun, and verb. Assign any values and print the complete sentence.

lessons.lesson_objective: Evaluate comparison expressions and predict their boolean results.

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create a variable number with any integer. Write expressions to check if it is even and if it is positive. Print both boolean results.

lessons.lesson_objective: Convert variables among int, float, str, and bool without errors.

exercises.exercise_instructions: Given the strings '12' and '3.5', convert them to appropriate numeric types, add them together, and print the result as a float.
Use input() to get a number from the user. Convert it to an int, then to a float, then to a string. Print all three converted values with their types.
